message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Factitious disorder is a mental illness where a person creates or exaggerates symptoms in order to gain attention or sympathy. In this case, the patient has a history of multiple hospital admissions with unexplained symptoms. Normal c-peptide levels would confirm a diagnosis of factitious disorder because it indicates that the patient is not actually hypoglycemic but rather intentionally causing his symptoms. The other options do not have a direct association with factitious disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Factitious disorder is a mental illness in which a person acts as if he or she has a physical or mental illness when he or she is not really sick. In this case, the patient has a long history of admissions for vague symptoms that could not be explained. Increased anion gap, the presence of norepinephrine and vanillylmandelic acid in the urine are not diagnostic for factitious disorder. Normal c-peptide levels, which are a marker of insulin secretion, would help rule out hypoglycemia caused by excess insulin administration, which is a common way for patients with factitious disorder to induce symptoms.

We refer to Mayo Clinic articles on factitious disorders for help. C-peptide levels are used to diagnose insulinoma, which can result in hypoglycemia. In this case, the patient’s blood sugar was low but not due to insulinoma, so normal c-peptide levels would confirm a diagnosis of factitious disorder. Increased anion gap is seen in metabolic acidosis, which is not relevant to this patient. Presence of norepinephrine and vanillylmandelic acid in the urine are seen in pheochromocytoma, but not factitious disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Factitious disorder refers to intentionally producing or faking physical or psychological symptoms in order to deceive others, and multivitamins could be used as a way to create abnormal test results. Among the options, normal c-peptide levels are an indicator that the low blood sugar is not caused by external insulin use and is more likely to be a result of factitious disorder. Increased anion gap is a nonspecific sign that can be seen in many conditions, while increased c-peptide levels suggest the presence of insulin in the body. Presence of norepinephrine and vanillylmandelic acid in the urine suggests the presence of a neuroendocrine tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Factitious disorder is a condition in which a person either knowingly or subconsciously fakes or produces symptoms of illness. C-peptide is a marker for endogenous insulin production, and since the patient has a low blood sugar level, normal c-peptide levels would confirm that the low blood sugar is not caused by insulinoma. Therefore, the correct answer is (B). The other options are not relevant to the diagnosis of factitious disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Factitious disorder involves the deliberate falsification of symptoms or production of symptoms in order to assume the role of a sick person. Normal c-peptide levels suggest that the patient did not administer insulin to create hypoglycemia, ruling out intentional hypoglycemia. The other options are not related to factitious disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Factitious disorder is a condition in which a patient intentionally produces or exaggerates illness symptoms to assume the sick role. Among the options, normal c-peptide levels would confirm a diagnosis of factitious disorder as it rules out hypoglycemia due to insulin use or secretion. Increased anion gap and presence of norepinephrine and vanillylmandelic acid in the urine do not necessarily confirm factitious disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Factitious disorder involves deliberate fabrication of symptoms or self-inflicted illness. Normal c-peptide levels would confirm a diagnosis of factitious disorder as low levels imply insulin administration, which is not seen in factitious disorder. The other options are not related to factitious disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Factitious disorder involves intentionally faking or exaggerating physical or psychological symptoms for no apparent reason. Among the options, normal c-peptide levels would confirm that the patient's hypoglycemic symptoms were not caused by insulin administration, which would support a diagnosis of factitious disorder. The other options are not relevant to this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Factitious disorder involves intentionally causing physical or psychological symptoms in order to assume the role of a sick person. In this case, the patient has a history of multiple hospital admissions for unexplained symptoms. Normal c-peptide levels would confirm the diagnosis, as high levels may indicate insulinoma, which would be a real medical condition and not caused intentionally by the patient. The other options are not related to factitious disorder.
